title: Primary Pseudoperfect Numbers
description: Are there infinitely many m such that ∑ 1/p = 1 − 1/m for some set of distinct primes P? These m are called primary pseudoperfect numbers. Only 8 are known (OEIS A054377). Each m equals the product of its primes.

overview.historicalContext: Erdős and Graham posed this in their 1980 monograph. The equation ∑ 1/p = 1 − 1/m with P a set of distinct primes leads to 'primary pseudoperfect numbers,' cataloged as OEIS A054377. Only 8 are known; the largest has 31 digits.
overview.problemStatement: Are there infinitely many integers m ≥ 2 such that ∑_{p ∈ P} 1/p = 1 − 1/m for some finite set P of distinct primes?
overview.proofStrategy: We formalize the solution set, the primary pseudoperfect property, verify known examples, state the product constraint (m = ∏P) and uniqueness, and connect to Egyptian fraction representations.
keyInsights: m must equal the product of all primes in P
At most one prime set P works for each m (uniqueness)
The equation rewrites as 1/p₁ + ··· + 1/pₖ + 1/m = 1 (Egyptian fraction of 1)
Only 8 primary pseudoperfect numbers are known
The known sequence grows extremely rapidly: 2, 6, 42, 1806, 47058, ...

sections.title: Core Definitions
sections.summary: Defines erdos313Solutions as the set of (m, P) pairs and IsPrimaryPseudoperfect for integers m admitting such a prime set.

sections.title: Main Conjecture
sections.summary: States the infinitude conjecture for both the solution set and the set of primary pseudoperfect numbers.

sections.title: Verified Examples
sections.summary: Records the first 5 known solutions: m = 2, 6, 42, 1806, 47058 with their prime sets.

sections.title: Structural Properties
sections.summary: The product constraint (m = ∏P), uniqueness of P for each m, and the count of at least 8 known solutions.

sections.title: Egyptian Fraction Connection
sections.summary: The equation rewrites as an Egyptian fraction representation of 1.

conclusion.summary: Formalizes Erdős Problem #313 on primary pseudoperfect numbers — integers m where the reciprocals of m's prime factors sum to 1 − 1/m. Includes known examples, structural constraints, and the Egyptian fraction connection.
conclusion.implications: The scarcity of solutions (only 8 known) combined with the rapid growth of known values makes this a challenging problem in elementary number theory.
openQuestions: Are there infinitely many primary pseudoperfect numbers?
Is there a 9th primary pseudoperfect number?
What is the growth rate of the sequence?
